content: Completely empty doc: https://hackmd.io/h_tyzNEKS_Kc2OY_rSm28g
we're going to have a meeting this week, compiler-team#484
Will start filling this out later today
(oop jack beat me to the first post)
Okay, so I think it's going to just be easier to write a thing with the code in triagebot to generate the backlog bonanza markdown. the github apis are giving me problems with the queries I want
Plus that will be good if/when we need to regenerate or update
Okay, I've filled in the hackmd with all the open tracking issues not labeled with other teams
Gonna make a triagebot PR shortly so others can do the same another time
triagebot#1586
Might have to trim some off the end here. There's no we getting through all of these and it's making hackmd extremely slow
Wait, I just reailzed: is today backlog bonanza? For some reason yesterday I thought that today was planning meeting
what is wrong with me

I've just realized by reading the comments around that this was my fault because I wrote "planning" instead on "steering" meeting in the agenda :face_palm: sorry @pnkfelix and t-compilerfor the confusion
Hi @Jack Huey ! I'm going to reuse this topic for doc preparation for this Friday's meeting
Cool :)
This should be pretty simple. Maybe just need to run the triagebot command to generate the hackmd
But I think I still have to make it ignore issues with a S-tracking-*
Or just manually remove those from the doc
ironically I did not have my zulip-id in the team's pnkfelix.toml, so triagebot doesn't want to listen to my privmsg'ed commands.
but also: I can just reuse the doc from the last meeting, no?

unless there are old issues that would previously not been included and that would be included if I were to make a fresh query. (I certainly not expect us to get through all of the backlog this Friday.)

what I will do right now, is move the issues that we have already processed to the bottom of the document (with the zulip log of the relevant meeting linked.). That will preserve its utility as a FIFO work queue.

Okay that's done. The main other thing I think is to try to follow through on this suggestion from Wesley:
Wesley Wiser said:

At least from the issues we went through today, there's probably a lot more that are either: not actually waiting on our team or are not actually tracking issues. Doing something more async would help us not waste too much time on those issues.
(I have some other meetings right now that I have to attend to, but I plan to circle back around to this later.)
Ah not a bad idea. Easy enough to start just going through those. I might have some time later today or tomorrow to do that too
Okay, I'm finally ready to continue with this
prepass: "Tracking issue for the "ptx-kernel" ABI" rust#38788
currently marked B-unstable, C-tracking-issue, O-NVPTX, T-compiler
here is an interesting (and relevant) comment on a PR that fixes a bug in ptx-kernel ABI: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/94703#issuecomment-1061177678
okay, here's how I see status, after reading comment thread on PR #94703:

1. This feature has fallen into disuse
  2. This feature is still of interest. (PTX is NVIDIA's low-level VM+ISA for describing CUDA GPU code)
  3. The feature has at least one codegen bug
  4. The feature may have design concerns, depending on what people expect its scope to be. (I'm basing this on the comment I linked earlier, but I'll also note that there's an immediate successor comment that essentially asks "can't we just narrow the scope to the bare minimum set of types," and I have to admit, I have the same question.)
rust#38802 is tagged as T-infra; removing from list
(I'm starting a few down to hopefully not step on toes)

for things like #94703, where I'm making non-obvious choices of what to do, I'm currently planning to just include them in a summary list at the top of the document, before the input queue for the meeting itself.
That works.

but it sounds like rust#38802 is so obviously not-ours that we needn't even both putting it in a summary list? I'm mostly just saying this so that you'll add things to the summary list too that warrant it (in terms of getting some eyeballs in the meeting itself tomorrow).
I was just going to leave a quick note under issues that we go through
okay, that works too.
prepass: "NVPTX backend metabug" rust#38789
pretty interesting comment thread on there
Removing rust#40474, since it's tagged as T-infra
Same for rust#40772

re rust#38789 I am probably going to need to find a domain expert to resolve some of the questions that were raised in the comment thread. At least, things like this 2018-02-21 comment make me wonder "is this S-tracking-design-concerns ? How many things have to be redesigned from the ground up to support CUDA?
rust#41710 is T-cargo; removing
Removing C-tracking-issue for rust#41710
rust#42117 is T-infra; removing
I'll just leave rust#38789 on the list for now.
I think it's perfectly reasonable to be conservative about removing things from the list
sure, much like unilateral backport decisions
(i have to step away for a bit, i'll be back later)
prepass: "Tracking issue for resolve_trait_on_defaulted_unit compatibility lint" rust#39216
it seems to me like this should fall into the category of a future-incompat warning before we make it a hard error
but ugh is issue #51125 still present in the compiler? nearly four years later? Lets find out
rust#43035 is T-infra; removing
rust#43461 is T-core; removing
rust#43535 is T-infra
